title: [spot] Interaction between `sky start [--force]` and spot controller's autostop
body:
User reported that:

>Is the spot controller autostopping actually working? When checking sky status, the comment says will be autostopped if idle for 10min  but the AUTOSTOP column shows nothing.

---

After digging into potential issues, we aren't sure why this happened. The below *could* be one reason:

We should either 
- disallow `sky start [--force]` on a (stopped) spot controller (which resets its autostop setting to 0); or
- ensure  `sky start [--force]` on a (stopped) spot controller properly restores its autostop setting

cc @Michaelvll

title: [Docs] Cloud IAM access requirements for SkyPilot
body:
When assigning people to our shared cloud account, I was wondering what's the minimal IAM access needed for SkyPilot to work instead of granting a full access owner. This can be relevant for people in industry who may not have full access to their shared corp account.
We probably want to investigate the access requirements in each cloud provider and document it in FAQ or even quick-start.

This PR is to robustify the user hash, to avoid getting empty user hash from the file. It could happen before when the program crashed before writing to the file.
https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/48d4a84865821b468d0a608ef4860d7f352859f0/sky/utils/common_utils.py#L55-L56

title: [Sqlite] Database is locked when refreshing the status
body:
From our user:
when running `sky status -r`, the following error occurs:

```
...
in backend_utils.py, line 1460, in _ray_launch_hash
global_user_state.set_cluster_metadata(cluster_name, metadata)
...
_DB.conn.commit()
sqlite3.OperationalError: database is locked.
```

The problem happens again in another `_DB.conn.commit()` in `_is_spot_controller_up()`.

For more context, the spot controller is manually deleted in the GCP console, and multiple spot jobs are then launched. It is possible that multiple status update for the spot controller is performed concurrently, causing the issue.

PS: the problem is temporarily fixed by running the following lines:
```
echo ".dump" | sqlite3 ~/.sky/state.db| sqlite3 ~/.sky/state.new.db
mv ~/.sky/state.new.db ~/.sky/state.db
```


A possible solution for this is to have the sqlite cursor (or connection) in context manager whenever it is used, instead of using a global cursor.

Do you think this is a valid solution @concretevitamin?

title: Command `sky status` confusion with local clusters
body:
When using only Sky onprem for the first time, `sky status` shows:

```
No existing clusters.

Local clusters:
NAME                USER  HEAD_IP         RESOURCES                 COMMAND                         
hello               test  54.167.205.58   [(no GPUs)]               sky launch -c hello -- echo...
```

This is confusing for initial users since `no existing clusters` conflicts with local clusters.

title: [Storage] Explain MOUNT mode consistency model in docs
body: It's unclear in the docs how and when data is written to S3/GCS, and how/if multiple writers can write to the same file. This should be clarified in the docs.

title: Always use autostop by default
body:
Hi, this is an amazing piece of software. I was wondering if there is any way to always run the cluster the `autostop` mode using the configuration from the yaml file? I don't want to always do `--idle-minutes-to-autostop --down` when launching the cluster...

Alternatively autostop can probably be used as a sensible default — we should always autostop because if we forget it we could end up with a large bill.

title: Refactor resources
[WIP][Azure] Fix azure race condition
body:
This PR fixes some race condition mentioned in #1408. However, these race conditions should be pretty rare, so I am not sure if they are the root causes (from my understanding, it is more likely due to operating the **same cluster at the same time**, but I cannot find related code in the test). For me I cannot reproduce any of those errors in #1408 after this fix.

Closes #1408

title: [AWS] Avoid key pair permission issue by using cloud-init for authorized keys
body:
Closes #1425 

This PR uses the cloud-init to setup the authorized keys to avoid using `ec2.describe_key_pairs` reducing the permission requirement.

Backward compatibility should be guaranteed by our old yaml content restoring mechanism.

Tested:
`rm ~/.ssh/sky-key*`
- [x] `sky launch --cloud aws` and ssh into the cluster
- [x] `sky launch --cloud aws --num-nodes 3` and ssh into the head and workers.
- [x] `./tests/run_smoke_tests.sh` (except #1408 )
- [x] `tests/backward_comaptibility_tests.sh`

title: [Catalog] Remove hardcoded A2 pricing URL & Fix a bug in A2 machine zones
body:
This PR removes the hardcoded URL we use for fetching A2 machine prices. Instead of directly getting A2 machine prices, we first obtain A2 machine "total" cost, which is A2 host VM price + A100 GPU price, from the GCP website (https://cloud.google.com/compute/vm-instance-pricing). Then we get the true A2 host machine price by deducting the A100 (or A100-80GB) GPU price from the total cost.

This PR also fixes a bug that our current GCP catalog does not contain the A2 machines in `us-west1-b`. This bug happens because https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/regions-zones is not correct.

![Screen Shot 2022-11-16 at 11 49 21 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/46394894/202387244-21a05364-7e72-4c92-a018-b997ceaf371a.png)

title: [AWS] Permission issues with DescribeKeyPairs
body:
We require `DescribeKeyPairs` permission in `auth. setup_aws_authentication()`, which is not checked in `sky check` and can fail the `sky launch` when not available.

```
botocore.exceptions.ClientError: An error occurred (UnauthorizedOperation) when calling the DescribeKeyPairs operation: You are not authorized to perform this operation.
```

TODO:
- [ ] Check if we can get around that permission.
- [ ] If not, add the checking in `sky check`.

title: [Onprem] Admin may not have passwordless `sudo`
body:
Currently Sky Onprem relies on the assumption that the admin can run `sudo` commands without a password. 

As of the moment, there seems to be no way to circumvent around this due to how `ray job submit` works, unless a different backend (such as Kubernetes) is used.

title: [Onprem] `sky admin deploy` fails to detect GPU
body:
Cluster has 1 node that has 1 2080 and 1 1080.

Running `lspci` shows only the `1080` GPU and hence it fails.

There needs to be a better way to detect GPU types, as @infwinston suggested in this [comment](https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/pull/1356#discussion_r1010937720).

title: [Bug fix] head_ip extraction from Ray stdout
body: When Skypilot infers the head_ip from the Ray output message, it can capture a few extra characters (“’\n\x1b[0m”) which end up beinbg appended to the IP, which causes failures if you try to use the command runner. This PR replaces that capture with a regex to exactly match the IP.

There's some workaround at the moment, but if this is officially supported he'd like to switch to these APIs.

title: [Global Regions] Add data fetchers into wheel
body:
Previously, the user cannot find the `data_fetchers` in the spot controller (or the user installing skypilot with pypi) because we did not include them in the skypilot wheel (missing `__init__.py`). As the `data_fetchers` are important for users who want to use the global regions, we would like to have them in the wheel.

The main change is to add `__init__.py`, and the other changes are mainly for formatting, as our formatter did not consider those files without the `__init__.py` file.

https://skypilot.readthedocs.io/en/latest/reference/faq.html#advanced-how-to-make-skypilot-use-all-global-regions

Tested:
- Launch a CPU instance, run the following commands on the VM.
- [x] `python -m sky.clouds.service_catalog.data_fetchers.fetch_aws --all-regions`
- [x] `python -m sky.clouds.service_catalog.data_fetchers.fetch_gcp --all-regions`
- [x] `python -m sky.clouds.service_catalog.data_fetchers.fetch_azure --all-regions`

title: [Storage] `Operation not supported` when `file.flush()` on mounted storage
body:
Bug report on slack from a user:

> Got this error when writing to an s3 mounted file:
> ```
> (node-3 pid=10175)     self.file.flush()
> (node-3 pid=10175) OSError: [Errno 95] Operation not supported
> ```
> seems to happen stochastically since it’s not the first flush() called that failed. Has this been observed before? We’re basically doing
> ```
> file.write("...some_json_string...")
> file.flush()
> ```
> every 100 gradient steps
>
> It also seems like once the error started happening, it kept happening.
> Also when checking the files, the sizes are 0.


Likely related to goofy's partial posix compatibility.

title: [Custom Image] Support CPU tags for `skypilot:` images?
body:
As a new user of the custom image tags (e.g., `skypilot:gpu-ubuntu-1804`) I was a little surprised to find CPU tags not supported. Docker images (e.g., [ray](https://hub.docker.com/r/rayproject/ray/tags), [tensorflow](https://hub.docker.com/r/tensorflow/tensorflow/tags), [pytorch](https://hub.docker.com/r/pytorch/pytorch/tags)) generally support this by either supporting an explicit `cpu` tagged image or image without any tags (e.g., `skypilot:cpu-ubuntu-1804` or `skypilot:ubuntu-1804`).

I understand they might be using the same image under the hood, but good to have explicit tags for CPU. Otherwise I'm left thinking only GPU images are supported.

title: Make `--all` default to true for `sky status` (looking for region info)?
body:
Users reported:

which suggests it's not clear `-a` will show this info.

> There seems to be only the region and the hourly price that is printed when adding -a, maybe worth making that the default?

Please vote on this if you feel region should be by default displayed, and/or hourly price.

We can try to clarify this “think of managed spot as a serverless job interface” concept at the top of the spot docs. Other explanations needed.

title: [UX] Disable ssh connection sharing for setup
body:
Our user raises that the ssh-agent forwarding fails for the setup step. The main reason caused by that we are using ssh connection sharing for the setup stage, which will make the `ssh-add` not take effect immediately when there is a master connection in the background without the forwarding setup.

Tested:
1. `ps aux | grep ssh | awk '{print $2}' | xargs kill`
2. `sky launch -c test-ssh test.yaml` (fails due to key permission)
```
setup: |
  git clone git://my-private-repo
```
3. `eval $(ssh-agent -s); ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_rsa`
4. `sky launch -c test-ssh test.yaml` succeeded (previously, this will fail due to the previous master connection still connected)
- [x] `sky launch -c examples/minimal.yaml`

title: Support multiple resources
body:
This PR supports specifying multiple resources with SkyPilot's programatic API and a basic YAML interface.

Python example:
```
import sky

task = sky.Task(run='nvidia-smi')

task.set_resources({
    sky.Resources(sky.AWS(), zone='us-east-1d', use_spot=True, accelerators={'K80': 1}),
    sky.Resources(sky.GCP(), accelerators={'K80': 1}),
})

sky.launch(task, cluster_name=f'my-cluster', stream_logs=False, down=False)
sky.exec(task, cluster_name='my-cluster', stream_logs=True)
```

Console output
```
(sky-tmp) weichiang@mbp sky % python examples/multi_resources.py
I 11-10 16:31:03 optimizer.py:610] == Optimizer ==
I 11-10 16:31:03 optimizer.py:621] Target: minimizing cost
I 11-10 16:31:03 optimizer.py:633] Estimated cost: $0.3 / hour
I 11-10 16:31:03 optimizer.py:633]
I 11-10 16:31:03 optimizer.py:689] Considered resources (1 node):
I 11-10 16:31:03 optimizer.py:718] ----------------------------------------------------------------------
I 11-10 16:31:03 optimizer.py:718]  CLOUD   INSTANCE          vCPUs   ACCELERATORS   COST ($)   CHOSEN
I 11-10 16:31:03 optimizer.py:718] ----------------------------------------------------------------------
I 11-10 16:31:03 optimizer.py:718]  AWS     p2.xlarge[Spot]   4       K80:1          0.27          ✔
I 11-10 16:31:03 optimizer.py:718]  GCP     n1-highmem-4      4       K80:1          0.69
I 11-10 16:31:03 optimizer.py:718] ----------------------------------------------------------------------
I 11-10 16:31:03 optimizer.py:718]
I 11-10 16:31:03 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:2790] Creating a new cluster: "my-cluster" [1x AWS(p2.xlarge[Spot], {'K80': 1})].
...
```
When AWS fails, we'll go to GCP.


YAML example
```
resources:
  cloud: aws
  use_spot: true
  accelerators: ['K80:1', 'V100:1']
```

TODO
- [x] basic YAML interface (a list of accelerators)
- [ ] Complicated YAML interface (should we do it?
- [x] ~~Add option to disable optimizer~~ honor user's preferred order when acc is list
- [ ] Grafana usage collection schema
- [ ] Smoke test

title: [Image] Support passing AMIs for different regions
body:
Closes #1345 

Main changes:
1. Support a dict for `image_id`
2. Added 3 smoke tests for the image_id dict.

Notes:
1. The failover will only go through the regions listed in the `image_id`.
3. If a region or zone is specified and not in the `image_ids`, it will throw an error.
4. If a task to be run on a existing cluster has a different `image_id` (even if it is the same in the same region the cluster is in), we will just error out.

Tested:
- [x] `sky launch -c test-image-dict test.yaml`
```
# test.yaml
resources:
  cloud: aws
  image_id:
    us-east-1: ami-0fb70a87623506e3e
    us-west-2: ami-03e40ee6f58eea284
```
- [x] `sky launch -c test-image-dict-failover test.yaml`
```
# test.yaml
resources:
  cloud: aws
  image_id:
    us-east-1: ami-0fb70a87623506e3e
    us-west-2: invalid
```
- [x] `tests/run_smoke_tests.sh test_image_id_dict`
- [x] `tests/run_smoke_tests.sh test_image_id_dict_with_region`
- [x] `tests/run_smoke_tests.sh test_image_id_dict_with_zone`

title: Improve UX for logs to include SSH name and rank
body:
As discussed in #1369, this updates the debug logs to make it easier to figure out which node is the head node, which host name to use to ssh into a specific node, and also the rank of the node. With this PR, the debug output becomes the following:

```
(node-2, head, rank=0, pid=23862) 0
(node-2, head, rank=0, pid=23862) 172.31.95.105 172.31.81.91 172.31.85.131 172.31.89.126
(node-0, worker1, rank=1, pid=22755, ip=172.31.81.91) 1
(node-0, worker1, rank=1, pid=22755, ip=172.31.81.91) 172.31.95.105 172.31.81.91 172.31.85.131 172.31.89.126
(node-1, worker3, rank=3, pid=22760, ip=172.31.89.126) 3
(node-1, worker3, rank=3, pid=22760, ip=172.31.89.126) 172.31.95.105 172.31.81.91 172.31.85.131 172.31.89.126
(node-3, worker2, rank=2, pid=22757, ip=172.31.85.131) 2
(node-3, worker2, rank=2, pid=22757, ip=172.31.85.131) 172.31.95.105 172.31.81.91 172.31.85.131 172.31.89.126
```

with the following config:
```
resources:
  cloud: aws
  disk_size: 1024
  instance_type: m6i.large

num_nodes: 4

run: |
  echo $SKY_NODE_RANK
  echo $SKY_NODE_IPS
```

Thus, if the cluster is named `mycluster`, the user can easily figure out which host name to use to ssh into a node using the logs e.g. `ssh mycluster-worker1` for the log corresponding to `worker1`.

To ensure stableness for the naming of workers, we first sort them by their external IP, then do a mapping from internal to external IP in the code generation step to determine the node name. This means that the node name is always the same for a cluster regardless of what value is passed via the `num_nodes` argument. 

This also updates the logic for determining the rank of node to use the external IP of a node rather than the internal IP. However, as discussed in #1291, the rank is not always constant for a cluster, and is assigned on a per-task basis, as can be seen from the following output with `num_nodes` set to 2:

```
(node-0, worker3, rank=1, pid=24355, ip=172.31.89.126) 1
(node-0, worker3, rank=1, pid=24355, ip=172.31.89.126) 172.31.95.105 172.31.89.126
(node-1, head, rank=0, pid=26036) 0
(node-1, head, rank=0, pid=26036) 172.31.95.105 172.31.89.126
```
## Questions
- Do we still want to respect the `task_name` variable that is passed in and display it? The above output includes the task name.
- Open to suggestions on how to further improve the UX!

## Tested
- [x] Multi-node cluster
- [x] Single-node cluster

title: [Core] Add support for detach setup
body:
Closes #730.

This PR adds the following option to `sky.launch` and `sky launch`: `--async-setup`

Note:
1. The setup will be run on all the nodes in the clusters no matter how many nodes are required by the task so that all the nodes will be in the same state to avoid inconsistent behavior on different nodes after many setups are run. (There is still a barrier after setup, i.e. the setups should finish on all the nodes before the `run` is executed).
2. Added a JobStatus called `SETUP` and a life cycle of a job will be `INIT -> SETUP -> PENDING -> RUNNING -> SUCCEEDED/FAILED`
3. Discussion: Should we combine the `--async-setup` and `--detach-run` together to `--detach`, i.e. `setup` and `run` will detach together?
  Pro: simpler API for the user
  Con: Less control, some user's logic will need to be changed if they rely on the previous behavior.
  My thought: We can add the `--async-setup` first in this PR, to see how people feel about this, and defer the combination.

title: Debug UX: easily know SSH name or public IP from log outputs
body: User asked > Is there a way to check which VM corresponds to which rank for a given job in the sky cmd line tool? When running a job the logs will show up by the node rank; I will need to know its corresponding IP / ssh name if I need to ssh into it and debug. It seems that sometimes it shows IP and sometimes it doesn’t, and these IPs are the private IPs rather than public ones. >One usability improvement is if there can be an easier way to map from the IP to the name I should use for ssh. Right now I will need to manually lookup whether this is head or one of the workers. ---- Difficulty of logging into `node-0`: - In general, `node-0` may not refer to the head node, whether `num_nodes` is equal to or smaller than num cluster nodes. (cc @iojw to confirm) - Therefore the user cannot look at the output above and do `ssh ` to log into `node-0`. Difficulty of logging into `node-i` where i > 0: - Output shows private IP. From the client machine, user doesn't know what to put in `ssh -worker` or `ssh `.

title: [Custom Image] Support tag for the images and global regions
body:
Add an `image tag` for choosing a list of images provided by sky. Currently, we don't support specifying the image tag for Azure, as we previously did for `image_id`, mainly because Azure has more complex image setting.

The `image_id` still needs to be specified with the clouds, since we don't align the system version and the cuda version for different clouds at the moment.
Please refer to https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot-catalog/pull/3 for the details of the catalog.

Suggested method for using all AWS regions besides the US regions:
```
cd ~/.sky/catalog/v4
python -m sky.clouds.service_catalog.data_fetchers.fetch_aws --all-regions

sky launch --cloud AWS
```

To launch a VM with Ubuntu 18.04
```
sky launch --cloud aws --image-id sky:gpu-ubuntu-1804
```

We also enforce the US regions will be tried first.

Tested:

title: [Feature Request] Support advanced AWS feature
body:
Current skypilot does not support advanced aws options like specifying security groups and placement groups, which is supported by ray autoscaler and boto3. These options are critical to our experiments. For example, the placement group can make sure the instances have high inter-connection speed.

cc @Michaelvll

title: [AWS] Add support for global regions in AWS

labels.name: do not merge
labels.description: do not merge this PR now

body:
This PR adds experimental supports for global regions for AWS.

We use US regions by default. The advanced users who would like to try the global regions will need to create a file: `~/.sky/config`
```
catalog:
  aws:
    preferred_areas: all # can be changed to ["us", "eu", "ap"]
```
I am planning to add a `sky config` CLI that can let the user to set some configurations for SkyPilot. After that, we will not let the user know about the existence of `~/.sky/config`. 

Please let me know how do you feel about this design @concretevitamin, @romilbhardwaj, @WoosukKwon and @ all?


Tested:
- [x] `sky launch --cloud aws --region ap-south-1`

title: Check ssh is not blocked
body:
This PR aims to resolve issue #1232. We check that we can access [portquiz.net](http://portquiz.net/) port 22 in `check_network_connection` and `ray_up`.

I have some concerns hardcoding `portquiz.net`, but I haven't found a better alternative. `portquiz.net` mentions they have rate limits but do not give exact numbers, so to be safe, I restrict the number of ssh port checks.

The ssh port check also raises a warning instead of raising an error. I don't want the ssh port check to exit SkyPilot if the user cannot access `portquiz.net` and I think a warning is plenty.

I haven't extensively tested this PR, but I want to get some feedback first. Any thoughts? @concretevitamin @Michaelvll @infwinston

Sometimes I run smoke tests and check back a few hours later to see if all passed. During this time, its possible some tests failed and left the VM running. 

Should we add an auto-down to all smoke test clusters? We could set the autodown interval to 1-2hr to give enough time for the developer ssh if required.
